comments.commentBody: Correction: the NPR interview link is http://kuow.org/post/olympia-actress-kate-hess-and-doctors-view-death

As a retired pulmonary/critical care physician, I found that paying attention to the spiritual as well as the physical aspects of a person gave me a better understanding of how to care for the patient and family - beyond the strictly scientific milieu. I don't care how brilliant the doctor may be, if s/he can't engender trust and show empathy (by dealing with the whole person), important aspects of care and communication will break down. This is particularly important when discussing a patient's wishes about end of life care which commonly have spiritual/religious aspects. For my take, please see my blog post http://www.endoflifeblog.com/2009/11/what-comes-next.html ; also my interview on NPR http://www.endoflifeblog.com/2009/11/what-comes-next.html

.
May Viv show the depths of her resolve while awaiting the promised repairs!!!

.
Himself and herself, to be specific.

And I liked her puzzles better when her middle name was "(C.C.)".

I know very well what it means to be a heavy drinker. One of my brothers - in - law drunk heavily and ultimately died having wasted much of his property, having caused unbearable pain to my sister and then two young kids. My sister, who is an introvert patiently brought up the two children and saved the remaining property.

My niece is a very strong willed person. She stood like a rock behind her mother even though her brother, who is elder to her, didn't understand his responsibilities then. This girl on her own passed many degrees including M.Phil and M.B.A and built up a house on their vacant land by taking loan apart from supporting her mother. By God's grace, as if some miracle happened, my nephew came to his senses. He stuck to his job and has become a responsible son for the past couple of years.

Being the elder brother, I did what little I could do financially to help my sister celebrate the marriage of my niece in a smooth way. I always used to worry about my sister in the past and now I am more than happy for their family.

first of all, most  loss in stores of all types is from employees, not customers. as far as other reasons why high-end stores don't come to poor areas, high-end means high prices, and it's a reasonable question whether locals will pay the freight. finally, there are other reasons regular stores don't come to these areas you know nothing about, like the difficulty of hiring employees and trucking in stock.

Hanging on to old habits and predispositions are luxuries some can afford. Insisting that others pay the freight for a 'comfort zone' is selfish, bullheaded and lazy. If creating coops, organizing fresh markets, and the like solves the food desert issue, the people with the problem should step up, rethink, and resolve them.

Defining oneself as worthy, hard working, responsible citizens has a disconnect with blaming a host of others for not solving the issue. Who are the great 'they'? The more worthy, the harder working and the more responsible?

The biggest problem there is the 'they', whoever they are, are not vested in solving the problem. Waiting around for it to happen is a misery of its own. How can I, we, fix this may be hard, it is less miserable.

Unemployment is not low, but it is down from its highs. So that would be 'for a few people', providing they are willing to work at any job available, anywhere one presents itself.

I love my work. Have four post graduate degrees. Work for a non profit. Make but a hair over the second quintile line for those eighty hour weeks.

Figure out what you love and do it for next to nothing....better than doing nothing and complaining.

Time for a farmers market & community garden.  Or the city, who has failed in its responsibilities could pick up the tab for all of it and hire contractors to bring produce, bread, meat, etc. in on long weekends until the super market is done.

Were there a market for a supermarket, private industry would provide one. The fact that supermarkets are closing in this area shows that the residents cannot support a full size supermarket, regardless of what big government types believe. The push carts that I see older people and walkers using could easily carry a week's worth of groceries.

Where I live, there are church volunteers who will assist these people with transportation. Aren't there such programs in New York City? Free markets and free peoples are the solution, not government intervention.

For the record, most Americans don't have a supermarket within walking distance of their homes. For those of us older, born-and-bred New Yorkers who are glad to have a corner grocery store fairly nearby, where we can pick up a quart of milk when we need one, along with some Birdseye frozen vegetables and a stick of butter, it's hard to imagine that not having a supermarket four or five blocks away is something to crab about.

And then, drive through Anywhere, USA, and one of the things one thinks is, "Where do they do their shopping around here?!" (Answer: Thirty miles away. That's the way it is.)

My mother's eldest sister was born on Sands Street, near the Brooklyn Navy Yard. The house no longer exists; it's been replaced by acres and acres of low-income apartment buildings.

My grandfather had a candy stand at Fort Greene Park, and my grandmother polished brass rails at various bars and restaurants; she also took home piecework. She made buttons; you know, the way the Chinese do nowadays behind locked doors near the Manhattan Bridge.

Of course, they couldn't afford to live in Fort Greene, which in the 1920s and 1930s (and through to the early 1970s) was a wealthy area. So like everyone else in those days, they lived elsewhere and made do.

Well, things change, don't they.

Yes, before I bought a car (in my late 30s, mind you), I used an old-lady cart to walk to a larger grocery store than the one on my corner. It wasn't a supermarket by any means, but it had what I needed.

As for fresh produce, well, for almost the first forty years of my life, my family ate Le Seur canned peas and Birdseye vegetables. And we were middle class.

And I still hardly ever take a cab. Maybe once every two years. And yet I do not feel deprived . . . .

For the record, it takes me half an hour to drive to a supermarket I like, a Stop 'N Shop near Sheepshead Bay. Before I had a car, it took me a good twenty minutes to shlep my old-lady cart to a decent-sized grocery store on Kings Highway to get stuff my corner grocery store didn't have. And then oy, pushing it home again up and down curbs, fully laden with groceries . . . Just saying. Life isn't easy.

There are many areas that are food deserts. These areas need real supermarkets! Then there are areas that aren't food deserts where shops get huge tax breaks to expand. (Moishes in Midwood comes to mind)
Unfortunately Community Boards, as they exist now, are far from democratic.
Was this problem really created by the government, or was it really created by greedy opportunists. That is the question.

While it's true that the neighborhoods mentioned in your article are lacking in affordable supermarkets, your article might also have mentioned other local sources of fresh produce: Greenmarkets and CSAs. Both exist in these neighborhoods, and the umbrella organizations that oversee them--grow.nyc for Greenmarket and Justfood.org for CSAs--go to considerable trouble to bring in low-income members. For too many New Yorkers, fresh produce is hard to find and unaffordable. Still, Greenmarkets and CSAs do provide options for New Yorkers at all income levels. I wish we had more of them.

There was never a diagnosis of "major depressive disorder." The DSM-IV & V do not list being 'depressed,' 'really depressed' or 'seriously depressed' as diagnoses.

Suicidal people, unless they have some different pathology, turn their depression in on to themselves. They do not kill 120+ people just so they can kill themselves.

No one has published a genuine psychiatric diagnosis (listed in the DSM-V) for this individual. They just keep repeating mindless psycho-babble. Which makes me wonder what they are NOT saying. And whether he was taking just SSRI anti-depressants and/or anti-psychotics. 27 years old is within the range for a 1st psychotic break. (Which, usually, is not predictable.)

I am pretty sure there is no Tarasoff vs. UC Regents in Europe to pre-empt doctor-patient privilege. They are nuts about privacy there.

If so, the doctor couldn't send it to his employer. If he wasn't a threat to himself or others, even in the US, you couldn't stop him from doing most things.

This is why the FAA no longer allows family physicians to complete flight physicals. You have to go to a certified physician to get one.

I have a neighbor who drives a garbage truck. The DOT requires him to go to a certified (garbage truck driver?) physician for his physicals.

It ain't like it used to be.

Read the DSM-V, none of the features of "major depressive disorder" say anything about mass murder or homicide. No diagnosis of 'major depressive disorder' has ever been revealed.

The pilot wasn't anything that you described. Everything you said is an entirely subjective 'symptom' that you made up. If I get to make up my own, entirely subjective, criteria for allowing you to work; I, pretty much, hold any possibility of your continued or future employment in my hand, to be exercised at my whim.
But first, he should have been banned from flying.  First things first.  His passengers were more important than him.
On what basis would a doctor know who a patient's employer even was or even what they do for a living?

DJS...thank you for pointing out two excellent examples of people who likely had a diagnosable mental illness but that nonetheless had a positive effect on the lives of many. Unfortunately, I think Jason is one of the far-too-many people who are so uncomfortable with or misinformed about mental illness that they group all people with mental illness into one basket and label them "crazy."
You're right. Andreas Lubitz's actions are correctly defined as a murder-suicide.

Unhappy...In the United States, physicians are in fact mandated reporters (they are required by law to notify the proper government agency if they suspect certain things are happening, like child or elder abuse); I'm not certain if doctors who perform flight physicals are required to notify the FAA about a potentially unsafe pilot, though that would be logical. In Germany, though, who knows what the rules are; though given that many European countries have very strong personal privacy laws, perhaps doctors there are not mandated to report a *potentially* unsafe pilot--only a *known* unsafe pilot.
